This bacterium is a spore-forming, Gram-positive organism that thrives in high-temperature environments, with an optimal growth temperature ranging from 55°C to 65°C. It is a chemoheterotrophic microorganism, capable of utilizing a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, xylose, and cellobiose, as its energy and carbon sources.

Thermochaetoides thermophila DSM 1495 is characterized by its rod-shaped morphology and the presence of endospores, which allow it to withstand adverse environmental conditions. It is an important player in the microbial communities found in geothermal habitats, contributing to the decomposition of organic matter and the cycling of nutrients in these ecosystems.

This species has been studied for its potential applications in biofuel production, biomass conversion, and other biotechnological processes due to its ability to thrive in high-temperature environments and its capacity to degrade complex carbohydrates.
